Robert E. Lee Prewitt.Action: Greets Private Angelo Maggio cordially upon arrival at the base.
Carries two heavy bags and approaches his new post without complaint.
Decides to transfer from Fort Shatter to G Company, despite the risks involved in changing units and environments.
Carries heavy barracks bags by himself and approaches the orderly room confidently, showing physical capability and mental readiness.

Has chevrons removed from his sleeves, indicating loss or removal of rank stripes, which might point to negative implications about his competence or career but it is unclear if this is due to incompetence or a conscious choice.
Smiles slightly in response to Maggio's comment.
Shrugs when asked why he transferred out of the Bugle Corps, giving a brief but sincere answer.
Responds to Maggio's invitation for a trip to town with a noncommittal 'Maybe.'
Transfers out of Bugle Corps despite potential disapproval, follows orders without complaint.
Interacts calmly and confidently with Maggio, smiling slightly and responding with measured replies.
Enters Dayroom, surveys environment casually and efficiently, prepares to play pool without hesitation.
Breaks the pool rack solidly on first shot, demonstrating skillful and confident behavior.
Responds calmly and respectfully to Sergeant Warden's brusque inquiry and follows him without complaint.
Engages in polite exchange by acknowledging Warden's reputation respectfully.
Looks at Maggio coolly but answers thoughtfully, acknowledging his reputation.
Responds calmly and politely during interaction with officers.
Responds respectfully and formally to the Company Commander, reports as ordered
Keeps personal reasons private when asked about transfer
Denies having trouble despite suspicion and accusations
Explains his personal reason for quitting bugle duty sincerely and straightforwardly.
Takes the reprimand and conversation with Warden and Holmes without sarcasm or resentment, listens respectfully.
Quietly admits he quit fighting due to injuring a fellow soldier who went blind.
Shows restraint and seriousness when discussing the injury incident, nods almost imperceptibly.
Firmly clarifies he does not want the entire fighting program disbanded despite his personal decision not to fight.
Doggedly states he doesn't see why any man should fight unless he wants to.
Does not respond further to Holmes' appeal, snaps to attention instead.
Doggedly refuses to fight unless a man wants to, showing personal principles but potential inflexibility.
Snaps to attention promptly after Holmes departs, demonstrating military discipline and responsiveness.
Remains silent and does not respond to Holmes’ challenges or pressures, showing restraint but possibly lack of social tact or political skill.
Rejects joining Dynamite Holmes' boxing squad despite Warden's warnings.
Declines to join Dynanite Holmes' boxing squad despite knowing it puts him at risk, showing confidence in his own soldiering ability.
States 'I can soljer with any man' confidently in response to challenge about soldiering skills.
Refuses to be pressured into boxing, which is politically motivated, and instead chooses to take his chances as a regular soldier.
Expresses belief that a man should make up his own mind and go his own way rather than just 'playing ball'
Responds with surprise and pleasure when given help to move his bags
Insists on making up his own mind and going his own way rather than simply 'playing ball' as others advise.
Readily accepts help with moving his bags when offered, showing practical judgment.
Makes a brilliant shot in pool, demonstrating skill and calm under pressure.
Does not respond to provocative heckling by other soldiers, maintaining composure.
Thanks Maggio after a tense interaction, acknowledging his sympathy and support.
Refuses to continue fighting, insisting on quitting despite peer pressure and threat of punishment.
Shows visible agitation and inner turmoil but maintains sincerity in expressing his stance.
Responds confidently and courteously to Warden's greeting, indicating calm readiness.
Inquires about Warden, showing curiosity and desire to understand his environment and comrades.
Smiles faintly with pleasure while marching with his platoon, showing engagement with the group.
Responds to commands with a slight frown and attempts to correct his marching step, demonstrating respect for group discipline.
Hops and changes step to align with platoon after being reprimanded, showing willingness to conform and cooperate.
Shows a slightly contemptuous smile while running laps as punishment, suggesting internal resistance or lack of sincere remorse.
Strips and assembles a rifle extremely quickly and efficiently, impressing others including Henderson and Maggio.
Runs laps on the cinder track with a faint smile despite being mocked and physically challenged.
Protests when instructor trips him unfairly during bayonet practice.
Trudges alongside Maggio after training, sharing camaraderie in mutual hardship.
Endures a month of intense pressure and physical/mental abuse without breaking or showing signs of giving in.
Maintains a stubborn smile initially despite growing humiliation and exhaustion, indicating resilience but possibly also stubbornness that could prevent adaptation.
Endures constant mocking and baiting from fellow soldiers like Galovitch and Wilson without retaliation.
Keeps pushing himself physically to exhaustion during training without showing complaint or bitterness outwardly.
Faces verbal abuse and strict commands from non-commissioned officers, showing no signs of hostility or resentment in response.
Works diligently and quietly at the kitchen sink, despite an overwhelming pile of pans dumped on him by Private Willard.
Looks ruefully at the growing pile of work but does not complain or show anger.
Responds passively to the negative, bossy gesture from Private Willard without confrontation.
Scrapes, washes, and rinses a large pile of cooking pans efficiently despite burden and pressure from others.
Shows no indication of complaint or failure while performing KP duty; continues steadily and reliably.
Barks angrily at Willard when criticized but also smiles warmly and acknowledges Maggio's cheerful antics.
Complains to Willard about inefficiency and defends the workload realistically, showing awareness of practical limits
Responds angrily when criticized, indicating a confident defense of own work pace
Smiles and acknowledges Maggio's hard work, showing social awareness and morale building
Smiles back warmly at Warden's teasing and offers to share any found pearl fifty-fifty, showing good-natured and sincere behavior.
Shows controlled anger without resorting to violence, restrains himself from throwing a heavy mug despite provocation.
Responds to taunts with direct verbal defiance, indicating toughness but not hostility beyond confrontation.
Remembers previous details clearly and accurately, showing good memory.
Refuses to be intimidated or manipulated by the Warden, standing firm on his principles.
Shows self-control by restraining himself from throwing the mug despite anger.
Engages in verbal standoff with the Warden, risking further punishment but maintaining dignity.
Hands over hands for fingernail inspection with a crisp, sharp, expressionless demeanor.
Responds tonelessly and is non-committal about joining the boxing team, showing a lack of engagement or friendliness.
Steps up crisply and gives a precise identification; holds out hands for inspection with a sharp, expressionless demeanor.
Responds tonelessly to Holmes' question about the boxing team, indicating a refusal or disinterest.
Maintains a perfect knot in his tie and an expressionless, controlled demeanor under scrutiny.
Gives his solemn word to Mrs. Kipfer to protect the club's future.
Responds with dry humor acknowledging heavy drinking among soldiers.
Grins and plays along with the receptionist's rules and fees in a friendly manner.
Acknowledges heavy drinking openly and responds with humor and honesty ('Because he is.'), reflecting confidence and social ease.
Gives a solemn word to Mrs. Kipfer that the club's future will be safe with them, showing reliability and a reassuring demeanor.
Asks straightforwardly what he gets for the dues before paying, indicating practical intelligence and attentiveness.
Transfixed by Lorene, seems enchanted by her presence, and accepts her invitation to sit down without hesitation.
Continues to gaze at Lorene rather than engage fully with the other girls introduced by Annette.
Is tongue-tied and hesitant when approaching Lorene, appears transfixed and distracted, unable to engage confidently in the social setting.
Calmly produces membership card to explain unfamiliarity with the place, responding honestly and straightforwardly.
Responds seriously and proudly when questioned about being a soldier.
Melts emotionally when Lorene expresses liking him, shows sincere connection.
Shows concern when a fight between Fatso and Maggio breaks out, looks over worriedly.
Intervenes physically by grabbing Maggio to prevent escalation of fight.
Responds firmly to being underestimated as a soldier and asserts his commitment with confidence.
Calmly intervenes to stop a potentially violent quarrel between Fatso and Maggio, showing situational awareness and control.
Hauls Maggio away from the piano to prevent conflict
Holds tight to Maggio's arm to keep him from reacting aggressively
Shows care and protective behavior toward Maggio in a tense situation
Hauls Maggio away from a potentially violent confrontation at the piano, holding him back to prevent escalation.
Does not escalate the conflict further and appears aware of the dangers posed by Fatso Judson, showing situational awareness.
Smiles at Lorene before noticing her interest in another soldier, then approaches her looking hurt and disappointed.
Engages Bill in conversation by asking about his experiences, showing interest despite personal discomfort.
Sits down disgruntled and somewhat withdrawn when realizing Lorene’s attention on another man.

Engages in a conversation showing awareness of physical skills and activities but openly admits his lack of knowledge or experience in these areas (surfboarding, mountain climbing, flying, deep sea diving).
Expresses sincere apology for previous behavior and insists that each person is unique and important despite appearances.
Shows concern about Lorene's feelings and willingness to call off their interaction if she remains mad.
Shares a quiet, relaxed moment with Lorene on the couch, arm around her shoulder, listening with interest and wonder to her story.
Shows a calm presence, making no effort to dominate the conversation or appear superior; simply engages sincerely with Lorene.
Allows Lorene to snuggle up to him and shares a moment of gaiety.
Dims in gaiety and avoids explaining 'The Treatment' to Lorene, showing reluctance to open up about his troubles.
Admits he doesn't like weakness and stands by his principles despite social pressure.
Shares a personal and painful story about accidentally injuring a friend in a boxing match, showing vulnerability and emotional depth.
Turns away from Lorene when tears appear, indicating a moment of emotional restraint but still sincere.
Engages in casual conversation with fellow soldiers, shows no hostility.
Responds wearily to 'The Treatment' but remains present among others.
Comments about 'Thirty-Year Man' and mentions Karelsen's nearing retirement with a tone that hints respect and realism.
Engages in a quiet, composed conversation contrasting his reasons for being in the Army, showing clarity and a measured demeanor.
Appears weary and worn out, showing signs of recent hardship ('been through another recent dose of The Treatment').
Joins others to listen to and encourage the music, contributes warmly to the creative process.
Suggests a collaborative creation of a 'Soldiers' Blues' and enthusiastically names it 'Re-enlistment Blues', fostering group inclusion and shared pride.
Engages spontaneously and constructively in group creativity, suggests 'Re-enlistment Blues' title, begins writing down lyrics, showing initiative and leadership.
Joins in songwriting and laughing along with others.
Maintains focus and silence, scrubbing floor despite being spat on and insulted.
Writes down the words of the song as they are composed, keeps up with the group, contributes actively.
Stops, stuck momentarily while writing lyrics, needs others' help to continue.
Keeps scrubbing the floor despite insults and spit from others, shows persistence and focus on task.
Refuses to clean up after being deliberately sabotaged, openly expresses anger and frustration toward Sergeant Galovitch.
Rejects an apology demand and asserts he is owed an apology instead, showing honesty and standing up for himself.
Refuses to continue cleaning after being provoked by deliberate sabotage and verbal mistreatment, showing controlled but firm resistance.
Talks back to a non-commissioned officer despite knowing the consequences and military protocols, indicating poor judgment in terms of military discipline.
Maintains dignity under provocation and refuses to submit to unfair treatment, demonstrating inner strength and confidence.
His defiance leads to a punishment detail with a demanding physical task rather than resolving conflict through more tactful means.
Persists in the arduous hike under heavy load despite exhaustion.
Shows no overt interaction or communication with Galovitch beyond the task, remaining focused and silent.
Hikes a steep dirt road carrying a seventy-pound pack in extreme heat, despite being sweat-soaked, puffing, and dog-weary.
Does not complain or quit under physically demanding conditions.
Obediently resumes hiking immediately after interaction with General Slater, showing discipline and focus.
Refuses to apologize to Sergeant Galovitch despite pressure and punishment.
Maintains an expressionless, tired demeanor under harsh treatment and physical strain.
Refuses to apologize to Sergeant Galovitch, standing firm despite pressure from superiors.
Maintains an expressionless, composed demeanor under physical and psychological stress (heavy pack, exhaustion).
Obediently follows orders to go back to Galovitch despite anticipating further hardship.
Refuses to complain about unfair treatment, stating he won't give satisfaction by squirming.
Refuses to complain or seek help despite having a valid grievance about excessive KP duty and unfair treatment.
Demonstrates self-control and restraint by deciding not to let others see him squirm even when faced with adversity.
Slaps the bugle away from Clark's mouth in an overwhelming, uncontrollable protest.
Wipes the mouthpiece on his sleeve, then plays a wild, violent obligato on the bugle that moves the room and reveals raw emotion.
Shows embarrassment and vulnerability after playing the bugle, indicating sincerity and emotional openness.
Plays a difficult, almost impossibly high note on the bugle with a pure tone that stops the noisy room and draws attention.
Slaps the bugle away from another player who hits a sour note and then takes over to play skillfully.
Stops playing suddenly after about fifteen seconds and puts the bugle down with embarrassment, the violent energy gone.
Remains uninvolved and passive while a violent conflict erupts involving his comrades, not intervening or deescalating.
Stays calm and composed while a violent confrontation unfolds nearby, maintaining self-control.
Does not intervene aggressively during the escalating fight, showing restraint even under provocation.
Follows Warden impulsively after hearing Maggio describe him as a good man.
Shows appreciation and astonishment at Warden's moment of human frailty.
Offers Fatso's knife to Warden as a souvenir.
Puts the knife away and shares a moment of mutual respect with Warden, displaying a thin smile.
Is overjoyed by Warden's offer of a weekend pass but is unable to express thanks verbally.
Shares a playful, intimate moment with Lorene on the beach, allowing her to cover him with sand and chuckling under the towel.
Keeps the knife as a souvenir and shares a moment of mutual respect without unnecessary words.
Responds thoughtfully and with a thin smile to Warden's comment about not enjoying life.
Is initially incredulous but then accepts Warden's offer of a weekend pass, indicating cautious trust and social intelligence.
Is somehow unable to express thanks properly when happy, showing some limitation in social/emotional competence.
Engages warmly and casually with Lorene at the beach, showing ability to relax and enjoy moments.
Describes his difficult past including being an orphan and feeling he didn’t belong until joining the Army.
Shows Alma the bugle mouthpiece, tries to share personal meaningful details.
Tries desperately to communicate the emotional significance of playing the bugle.
Mentions he was chosen to play Taps at Arlington, possibly boasting.
Enlisted in the Army at Fort Myer and learned practical skills like boxing and playing the bugle.
Was selected to play Taps at Arlington Cemetery, demonstrating recognized skill and trustworthiness.
Struggles to communicate the significance of his bugle playing to Alma, showing some difficulty in social or emotional expression.
Recognizes Maggio's drunken, desperate state and advises him to return to the Post immediately.
Engages Maggio calmly, offers him a cigarette, and tries to manage the situation without escalating conflict.
Allows Maggio to continue drinking and making a scene without intervening further or seeking help.
Expresses affectionate mixed feelings about Maggio, saying he makes him laugh and cry at the same time.
Shows concern for Maggio's behavior when Maggio suddenly dashes off to swim, noticing something worrying off-screen.
Glances gratefully at Alma when she suggests he look out for Maggio, then hurries to follow Maggio carrying his tie and shoes.
Finds Maggio sleeping on a bench and despite circumstances, smiles and gently shakes him awake.
Returns Maggio's clothes and interacts with him without anger or scolding, showing patience and kindness.
Pulls Maggio off the bench and tries to drag him away from the light to avoid trouble with MPs.
Commands Maggio to be quiet and come quietly to avoid getting into trouble.
Attempts to remove Maggio from a risky situation quietly and efficiently, showing awareness and caution.
Reacts aghast when Maggio deliberately attracts the MPs’s attention, potentially worsening their situation.
Starts toward the fracas horrified but does not intervene immediately when Maggio tells him to back off and that he is handling it.
Obeys Maggio's command to stay out of the fight and retreats quickly when threatened with a pistol.
Shows vulnerability by convulsively sobbing with his head dropped in the dirt after the fight with the MPs.
Sits miserably alone with a tense expression, not engaging with others in the orderly room.
Dives quickly and skillfully into bushes to evade gunfire from MPs, showing situational awareness and physical agility.
Ends up overwhelmed and subdued by the MPs during the fight, unable to knock out Maggio or escape capture.
Appears miserable and tense in the orderly room, internalizing defeat and frustration but showing composure by sitting quietly.
Calmly listens and nods when Warden suggests going to the Day Room, showing situational awareness and restraint.
Half-way to the door but stops when the phone rings, indicating alertness and responsiveness to command signals.
Does not protest or lose composure after hearing about the six months punishment, showing emotional discipline.
Moves up close to Maggio and apologizes for what happened to him, expressing remorse and responsibility.
Feels heartsick as he watches Maggio being taken away, showing emotional concern and empathy.
Holds Alma's hand as they walk up the steep cliff road together.
Expresses that seeing Alma helps him endure The Treatment.
Comments about not having cab fare, choosing to walk with Alma instead.
Shows genuine amazement and appreciation of Alma's house.
Introduced warmly to Alma's roommate Gorgette by Alma.
Grins and shows open interest in Gorgette's books, comments positively about her potential relationship with Maggio.
Responds warmly to Alma's hospitality, expresses comfort and a sense of companionship.
Dances with Alma despite awkwardness, expresses love sincerely and vulnerably.
Shows nervousness and tenderness when confessing feelings, demonstrates trust and sincerity.
Misses a step and stumbles while dancing.
Expresses love honestly despite his nervousness and hesitation.
Shows emotional vulnerability and depth in his confession, indicating internal strength despite obvious awkwardness.
Is afraid to broach difficult topics, indicated by trembling fingers and hesitance.
Earnestly discusses plans for a future with Alma, showing commitment and sincerity.
Accepts Alma's disparaging joke about his social status without bitterness, with a hurt but gentle reply.
Shows vulnerability by revealing personal hopes and a plan for bettering their life together.
Possibly naive or unrealistic about his situation with Captain Holmes, but speaks with openness about it.
Confidently asserts he could win the middleweight boxing championship even without training, showing belief in his skill and capability.
Engages sincerely and thoughtfully in a serious conversation about marriage and future plans, revealing emotional intelligence and reflective insight.
Accepts Alma's rejection with bitter disappointment but maintains admiration for her resolve and plans, demonstrating maturity and emotional control.
Assures Alma that nobody lies about being lonely, responding sincerely and supportively.
Calls Fatso 'a good boy' in response to Nair's story, shows concern for Fatso's condition, and expresses fury over the abuse Fatso is receiving.
Pulls up a clump of sod and throws it down with all his might, indicating frustration and emotional investment.
Asks genuinely if Fatso is going to be all right, showing care and empathy.
Shows visible anger and frustration on learning about Fatso's brutal treatment but does not intervene directly or escalate the situation.
Asks practical and relevant questions about Fatso's condition and prospects, demonstrating awareness and concern.
Faces intimidation from Galovitch without backing down, implicitly showing some psychological strength and confidence.
Decides to confront Galovitch physically despite the antagonism, shows cold decision in his eyes, shoves Thornhill aside to assert himself.
Controls himself initially while dealing with Galovitch's provocation, showing restraint before losing control.
Starts unbuttoning his shirt quickly to prepare for a fight, demonstrating readiness and confidence.
Engages in a potentially reckless fight rather than seeking a less confrontational solution.
Continues his attack focused on the body in the fight, showing persistent and skillful fighting technique.
Sustains a physically demanding fight, continuing despite injuries and fatigue, while confusing and outmaneuvering his opponent with skillful tactics.
Shows perseverance and tactical ability during a fight admired quietly by skilled peers.
Maintains fighting spirit despite being backed against the crowd and falling over feet, does not show weakness.
Fights Galovitch with skill and decisiveness, shows no animosity outside of the fight context.
Stops fighting immediately when order is given, shows restraint despite provocation.
Refuses to obey a non-commissioned officer’s order, leading to confrontation.
Does not retaliate after being provoked; crowd and fellow soldiers defend him.
Dodges easily and dominates the fight with effective punches, showing clear command of the situation.
Refuses a direct order from a non-commissioned officer, provoking a conflict that could have been avoided.
Calmly handles confrontation by stating he is not stepping into a ring, showing control over the situation.
Stares after the non-coms quietly after they walk off without escalating the conflict.
Joins in communal singing and laughter with Clark and Anderson, sharing beer and humor.
Engages in light, friendly conversation, asking Clark the reason for his nickname.
Stands among friends enjoying the moment despite physical and emotional scars (battle marks), indicating trust and camaraderie.
Engages in camaraderie and singing despite being visibly drunk and physically marked from a battle.
Stands up showing marks of a recent physical fight (with Galovitch), demonstrating toughness but appears physically worn.
Responds to Warden's challenge calmly and calls himself a friend.
Accepts whisky bottle from Warden and shares drink together, sitting down casually nearby.
Engages in a candid, sympathetic conversation about the misery of their life.
Stops automatically and responds appropriately and confidently to challenge by the warden at night, showing alertness and good situational awareness.
Weaves while walking after a rough fight, which may indicate some physical impairment or lack of steadiness.
Accepts drink and sits down matter-of-factly with a superior without showing disrespect or hesitation, demonstrating social ease and emotional composure.
Refuses to desert a friend in need despite danger, showing loyalty and moral courage.
Stays with Warden in a desperate and dangerous situation, showing determination and resilience.
Shows gravely listening attitude and gives encouraging responses when Warden expresses fears and hopes.
Tells Warden he is not scared and supports him in his fear about becoming an officer, sharing a solemn moment and passing the bottle
Hesitates briefly when mentioning his girlfriend Lorene, indicating some vulnerability but still shares personal info
Smiles and shares a moment with Warden as if sharing a secret known only to them
Remains calm and does not react aggressively when Sergeant Stark angrily confronts him and Warden
Calmly does not react to Stark's sudden aggressive approach; maintains composure when confronted unexpectedly at night.
Hesitates when mentioning his girlfriend's name.
Offers philosophical insight saying 'A man should be what he can do,' showing confidence in personal ability.
Defends and supports Warden by insisting others protect him, calling him the best soldier in the company.
Jumps up with Warden to catch the drunken Maggio as he is about to fall.
Insists confidently that Warden is the best soldier in the company and demands others take care of him, showing faith in his comrade's competence.
Jumps up quickly to catch the staggering Maggio, reacting promptly to an unexpected situation, showing physical readiness and alertness.
Comforts and helps the injured Maggio, insists on getting him to the hospital.
Reassures Maggio that he will not be sent to the stockade.
Takes charge by immediately organizing to get Maggio to the hospital after his injury.
Reassures Maggio that he will not be sent to the Stockade, demonstrating calm confidence.
Listens carefully and attentively to Maggio’s advice about handling Fatso and the Stockade.
Bends over, picks up Maggio, holds him gently and unbelieving after he is pronounced dead
Leans over Maggio's body in the jeep and adjusts it to prevent his head from bumping
Carefully carries the wounded Maggio, adjusts his position to prevent further injury while others assume he is dead.
Refuses to accept Maggio is dead without his own assessment, showing confidence and presence of mind.
Plays Taps with visible emotion and tears, evoking kinship and sadness among fellow soldiers.
Hands the bugle to Clark respectfully, allowing him to treat the instrument as hallowed.
Leans against the building watching Fatso Judson with relentless hatred on his face.
Calls out to Fatso in a toneless, ominous voice and arranges a private confrontation.
Blows the final notes on the bugle with visible emotion but maintains composure to carefully put away the instrument and exit respectfully.
Waits patiently and watchfully outside the New Congress Club, showing calm vigilance and deliberate control despite intense hatred.

Initiates direct confrontation with Fatso Judson in a measured, controlled manner, inviting to talk privately with a toneless and ominous voice, demonstrating confident social and psychological skill.
Engages in a tense confrontation with Fatso, shows calm and controlled demeanor.
Accuses Fatso of killing Maggio and seeks personal justice.
Anticipates Fatso's knife attack and steps swiftly aside, showing readiness and skill in combat.
Carries a knife identical to the one Fatso used against Maggio, indicating preparedness and awareness.
Engages confidently in a knife fight in a low-light environment, demonstrating courage and proficiency.
Despite being badly wounded and bleeding heavily, Prew attempts to continue moving and manages to tend to his wounds by using a handkerchief to slow the bleeding.
Prew staggers away from Fatso after killing him, showing perhaps confusion or emotional difficulty in the moment.
Prew reflects quietly on his scars and past, demonstrating introspection but no immediate practical action.
Allows Alma to care for him despite his condition, manages a smile at her concern.
Keeps to the shadows while struggling physically, does not reach out for help immediately.
Knocks out opponent in the sixth round of a fight despite injuries
Keeps moving and pushing through intense pain and serious injuries
Falls into Alma's house obviously wounded and in pain
Manages to smile despite agony and serious injury
Weakly reassures someone by saying 'Don't worry... Ain't gonna die.' and manages a smile.
Maintains a weak but confident statement that he won't die and that he is being saved for better things.
Gives a silly smile and attempts to lighten the mood when approached by Gorgette.
Is the subject of a report condemning Captain Holmes for cruelty and unauthorized tactics trying to force him to join the boxing team, showing Prewitt's resistance and integrity.
Reflects on losing respect of men and leadership qualities, but does not show evidence of regaining or maintaining command or confidence.
Shows internal awareness of the loss of men’s respect and his failure as a leader.
Said 'a man has got to go his own way... if he don't, he's nothin'' to Warden, showing strong personal integrity and self-reliance.
Went AWOL, which is unusual for him and implies he might be in trouble but is not typically shirking responsibility.
Refuses to sign the Officers Application despite pressure, indicating a firm personal conviction and refusal to compromise his principles.
Goes AWOL, which is concerning behavior for a soldier and might indicate poor judgment or trouble managing military obligations.
Sings softly and writes the Re-enlistment Blues despite being disheveled and in pain.
Nods blankly and does not respond when Alma speaks to him, showing inattentiveness.
Pours himself a drink and smiles faintly, engaging with Alma in a subtle, sardonic manner.
Laboriously writes out the Re-enlistment Blues and sings softly despite physical pain and drunken stupor.
Is disheveled, slovenly, stone drunk after days of drinking, has difficulty focusing on Alma’s words.
Moves stiffly, favoring his side, contorted face but still manages to pour himself a drink and interact.
Responds with a faint smile and ironic toast despite personal suffering, showing presence of mind.
Counts days of being AWOL accurately, plans to return to duty under his own power once healed.
Is deeply affected emotionally, unable to clearly explain why he killed a man.
Considers running away or drastic life changes (going to Mexico, being a cowboy), showing indecision.
Demonstrates persistence by composing and working on a song despite personal turmoil.
Misidentifies the Japanese attack as a German attack and mutters confusedly during a crisis.
Collapses from a hangover and mental disorientation during an emergency alert.
Listens to the radio in confused disbelief after hearing about Pearl Harbor, then urgently calls for Alma, showing concern.
Listens carefully to the radio broadcast about Pearl Harbor, shakes off grogginess, processes the information step-by-step before reacting.
Suddenly wrenches himself off the couch and immediately tries to gather Alma's attention after understanding the gravity of the situation.
Yells at the radio in rage, expressing pride and loyalty for the Army and riflemen.
Nods briefly at Alma and Gorgette but quickly turns back to the radio, minimal engagement with them.
Listens intently and reacts with focused rage to the radio broadcast detailing the attack on Pearl Harbor, showing engagement and a clear understanding of military matters.
Hurriedly dresses while maintaining attention on the situation, preparing to act quickly and decisively in response to new events.
Explains confidently to Alma and Gorgette about the unique skill of his army using the 'shooting gunsling,' implying pride and knowledge of his own military unit's competence.
Insists on returning to the Post despite being unfit and AWOL, showing dedication but ignoring Alma's emotional pleas.
Responds to Alma's concern with obsession over duty rather than comforting her, shakes head as if focused solely on his mission.
Laughs wildly about military constraints, displaying a somewhat carefree attitude about his situation, but does not engage in emotional support.
Decides to return to the Post despite being weak and AWOL, showing confidence and determination.
Laughs off warnings about punishment, showing situational awareness about the army's needs.
Plans to use back roads to avoid MPs and get into the West gate, demonstrating tactical thinking and confidence in his identity as a soldier.
Ignores others' advice to stay till morning and pushes through despite risks to himself, showing resolve but potentially reckless persistence.
Holds Alma closely for a moment before moving her away and leaving despite her desperate pleas.
Explains simply and sincerely that he is a soldier when questioned.
Responds to Alma's emotional appeals with quiet, firm resolve, indicating confidence in his identity and decisions.
Cuts off emotional manipulation by calmly leaving the room, demonstrating self-control and decisiveness.
Grins while acknowledging the long term of his military commitment, showing a subtle wit and acceptance of circumstances.
Despite being wounded and exhausted, he attempts to stealthily move across the road to get home, showing determination and some tactical awareness of his surroundings.
Begins to run away when challenged by MPs but then slips to one knee and behaves like a terrified, senseless animal, picking up a rock which is an unclear or irrational action in this context.
Flings a rock desperately toward the jeep's lights to try to escape.
Yells 'I'm a soljer!' to the MPs despite being pursued.
Throws a rock to disable the jeep's headlight and attempts to elude pursuers using zigzag movement and terrain to his advantage.
Confronts superior firepower and gets shot while trying to escape, ultimately failing to evade capture or harm.
Mentally prepares himself carefully for a critical action, focusing on doing it well and efficiently.
Maintains calm and concentration under pressure, reflecting confidence in his own skill.
Wrote the poem 'Re-enlistment Blues' and sang it with comrades, played Taps on bugle
Was recognized by fellow soldier Warden as a 'good soldier' and friend
Identified as a good soldier by a fellow soldier despite being found dead without regular identification.
Carries personal items such as bugle mouthpiece and a poem indicating dedication to military life and discipline.
No explicit demonstration of skill or strategic behavior in this excerpt; mainly posthumous recognition.
Responds thoughtfully and coolly to Maggio's compliment about his bugling skill.
Springs to attention promptly when ordered by Warden.
Enters the captain's office confidently and comes to attention properly.
Efficiently and brilliantly fast at stripping and assembling rifle, admired silently by Maggio.
No direct interaction or communication with others during task, focus is on mechanical skill.
Refuses to fight despite peer pressure and consequences.
Avoids explaining 'The Treatment' and his situation to Lorene, showing restraint.
Uses drinking as a way to cope, showing some impairing behavior.
Is pleased to see Maggio and shows concern for him despite Maggio's drunken and desperate state, gives him a cigarette and advises him to return to the Post
Engages in light conversation with Maggio, showing patience and tolerance
Boxes skillfully, moves quickly and cleverly, drives attack at opponent's body with intention and control.
Avoids hitting the head despite advice and opportunity, seemingly haunted and distracted by past trauma, flinches without being hit and is staggered several times.
Backs away from Fatso after Fatso accuses him of killing him, showing no words of comfort or remorse.
Smiles wearily and mumbles to himself about his scar after being wounded, indicating self-reflection and a quiet resilience.
Reflects silently on past family scars and losses while alone and injured, showing internal sorrow but no expressed connection to others in this moment.
Looks at Alma hurt when she admonishes him, then moves away mumbling; shakes his head sadly when asked why he killed a man.
Sings softly and affectionately to himself, testing the last couple of lines of a song.
Responds to Alma's frustrations with quiet, withdrawn behavior (mumbling, moving away).
Despite being severely wounded, attempts to get home rather than give up, showing determination and a vulnerable, sincere side.
Upon being confronted by MPs, reacts like a frightened animal and picks up a rock in desperation, showing fear and distrust.
